issues.description: The problem statement (and UML) require a constructor that initializes all five attributes in the order: lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfLecturers, numberOfTutors. The template provides a public constructor with only three parameters (lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, numberOfGuestStudents). The solution implements a constructor with the full five parameters. Having a mismatched constructor signature in the template can confuse students: they may think the three-parameter constructor is correct and wonder whether to modify or overload it, and it contradicts the explicit task to "Create a constructor that initializes every attribute" and the UML ordering requirement.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template constructor signature match the specification/UML. Either (a) change the template constructor to public Lecture(String lectureName, int numberOfInscribedStudents, int numberOfGuestStudents, int numberOfLecturers, int numberOfTutors) and leave the body with a TODO for students to implement the assignments in the specified order, or (b) remove the incorrect three-parameter constructor entirely and provide a correct stub (with the five parameters) so students implement the intended constructor order. This keeps the template aligned with the problem description while preserving the pedagogical task.
